articles.title: Postpartum Care in the First Weeks

content.headline: Navigating the First Weeks of Postpartum Recovery
content.intro: The initial weeks after childbirth are a critical period of physical recovery and emotional adjustment. Understanding what to expect and how to care for yourself during this transformative time can make the transition to motherhood smoother and more manageable. Remember, recovery is a journey that requires patience and self-compassion.

sections.title: Physical Recovery in Early Postpartum
sections.content: Your body undergoes significant changes as it heals from childbirth:
points: Vaginal bleeding (lochia) can last 4-6 weeks - use maternity pads
Uterus shrinks back to pre-pregnancy size over several weeks
Perineal soreness or episiotomy healing requires careful hygiene
Breast engorgement occurs as milk supply establishes
Afterpains (uterine contractions) help control bleeding
Hormonal shifts cause night sweats and hair changes

sections.title: Essential Self-Care Practices
sections.content: Prioritize these recovery strategies in the first weeks:
points: Rest whenever possible - sleep when your baby sleeps
Stay hydrated and eat nutritious, easy-to-prepare meals
Use ice packs or warm compresses for perineal discomfort
Take pain relief as recommended by your healthcare provider
Practice gentle movement like short walks to aid circulation
Wear comfortable, loose clothing and supportive bras

sections.title: Emotional Wellbeing and Support
sections.content: Mental health is as important as physical recovery:
points: Expect mood swings and emotional sensitivity (baby blues)
Accept help from family and friends with meals and chores
Share your feelings with your partner or support person
Be patient with yourself - adjustment takes time
Watch for signs of postpartum depression beyond normal mood swings
Connect with other new parents for shared experiences
